instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello, working on a no boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Here are the measurements taken so far

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>: 14.7v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL>: 14.7v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 14.7v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>: 3.23v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL>: 4.99v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 5.019v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 0v

Measured <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> to be 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm wondering how you get S4 voltages if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is low...
Are you sure about these values?

However <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> should be present at same time.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is table at 0V?
Check if pulses at least when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is for sure a stable 5 volts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I rechecked both <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> and only the <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> is present and stable.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is stable at 0v.

Used oscilloscope and check the <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and it did pulse once up to 3v approx for about a second before it dropped out. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> also pulses to 3v approx and drops to ov.

Resistance to ground for <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: stabilized to 70K approximately (reading was unstable at first, like i was measuring a capacitive circuit in resistance mode. In diode mode, i'm get 0.766).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Possibly bad <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> should drop at same moment as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>.
Check if all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse, once at least.
If yes, check if corresponding Sx voltages pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi guys any news regarding this issue?
I have the same exact one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No booting up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Never got this done. Owner did want to wait anymore, so had to return the computer.
